Comment: Hi all! This is a game between me and my long-standing Arch-Rival, who has only recently come to GameKnot. He is playing White, and before this game the score between us is 1.5-1.5. So there's a lot to play for...

I play the move for Black which points the way to main line Queen Pawn openings, such as the King's Indian, Nimzo-Indian, or Benoni. The benefit of this move is that Black has more or less complete freedom to choose the opening.
Pointing the way to a King's Indian Defence.
Pointing the way to a King's Indian Defence.

This solid move, my Arch-Rival told me, is often played to bypass the sharp play and the theoretical lines of the King's Indian Defence, also blunting Black's fianchettoed bishop. Annoying for me, as I am more comfortable with main line KID.
Both sides develop, in nearly symmetrical fashion.

I prefer keeping my queen in a central, dominant position with ...Qd7, than hide in the corner with ...Qf8. This is a CRITICAL BLUNDER BY ME.
I recapture my queen. I had, yes, foreseen lines with 21.Re8+ Bf8 22.Rb8 Rd2, which I think are narrowly advantageous for me.

AAAAARGH!!!!!!!! No! Dead in the water! Thwarted by an irritating bishop attack! Why? This is exactly as GM Yasser Seirawan describes this combination in "Winning Chess Combinations" and I fell right for it! No! An embarrassing loss against my ARCH-RIVAL!
